DataElement.preferredName: Heart Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction Reduced Function
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator whether there was a reduction in the function of how much blood the left ventricle of the heart pumps out with each contractionn from the baseline.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Heart Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction Reduced Function
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to a reduction in the function of how much blood the left ventricle of the heart pumps out with each contraction.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A hollow muscular organ which receives the blood from the veins and propels it into the arteries. It is divided by a musculomembranous septum into two halves -- right or venous and left or arterial -- each of which consists of a receiving chamber (atrium) and an ejecting chamber (ventricle). SYN cor, coeur.

Concepts.definition: A hollow organ located slightly to the left of the middle portion of the chest. It is composed of muscle and it is divided by a septum into two sides: the right side which receives de-oxygenated blood from the body and the left side which sends newly oxygenated blood to the body. Each side is composed of two chambers: the atrium (receiving blood) and ventricle (ejecting blood).

Property.preferredDefinition: The ejection fraction (or, more correctly, left-ventricular ejection fraction, often abbreviated LVEF) is a measure of how much blood the left ventricle of the heart pumps out with each contraction. With each beat, a normal heart ejects about one-half to two-thirds of the blood in its left chamber. (Wikipedia):Reduced; made less in size or amount or degree.:Function; what something is used for.

Concepts.longName: Measurement of Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction
Concepts.definition: A measure of how much blood the left ventricle of the heart pumps out with each contraction. With each beat, a normal heart ejects about one-half to two-thirds of the blood in its left chamber.
Made less in size or amount or degree.
The normal action performed by a structure or device.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Has the patient experienced a
